study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether neonatal glutamine supplementation in very preterm children affects head circumference growth and brain structure volumes at school-age.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation was associated with increased head circumference growth in the first year of life but not with weight or length growth. Head circumference growth was positively correlated with white and grey matter volumes at school-age.
population_specificity: Very preterm children (<32 weeks gestation).
study_duration: Intervention duration not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of glutamine supplementation on neutrophil function, particularly reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, in male university judoists undergoing intensive training.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation increased ROS production activity one week after exercise and prevented excessive muscle damage and suppression of neutrophil function during intensive training, unlike the control group. Myogenic enzymes increased post-exercise but remained unchanged in the glutamine group.
population_specificity: 26 male university judoists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the consensus on supplementing important micronutrients, including glutamine, in critically ill patients undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
results_summary: The study found a consensus to supplement glutamine and other micronutrients in CRRT patients, though strong evidence was lacking. The abstract suggests glutamine is considered beneficial but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients in intensive care units undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intravenous glutamine supplementation could reduce chemotherapy-induced toxicities (e.g., mucositis, hematological issues) in children with non-Hodgkin lymphoma.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation showed no significant differences in mucositis rates, hematological parameters, gastrointestinal/hepatic toxicities, febrile neutropenia duration, or hospitalization length compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children aged 48–120 months with non-Hodgkin lymphoma receiving chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of glutathione-enhancing agents, including N-acetyl cysteine and liposomal glutathione, on restoring glutathione levels in macrophages from HIV-infected individuals and their impact on controlling Mycobacterium tuberculosis growth.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with N-acetyl cysteine or liposomal glutathione replenished reduced glutathione (rGSH) levels and correlated with decreased intracellular growth of M. tuberculosis. HIV infection was associated with increased free radicals, decreased GCLC production, and depleted rGSH, potentially contributing to impaired innate immune function.
population_specificity: Macrophages isolated from individuals with HIV infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of whey protein and leucine ingestion, which included glutamine, on neutrophil function and immunomodulators during recovery from intense cycling.
results_summary: LEUPRO ingestion increased plasma glutamine and other amino acids, reduced neutrophil O2 production acutely post-exercise, and increased neutrophil oxidative burst by day 6, suggesting modulated neutrophil function during recovery.
population_specificity: 12 male cyclists undergoing high-intensity training.
effective_dosage: Not specified for glutamine alone; part of a mixed supplement (20 g protein, 7.5 g leucine, 89 g carbohydrate, 22 g fat per hour).
study_duration: 6 days of high-intensity training with post-exercise supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine supplementation reduces mortality and complications like gram-negative bacteremia in burn patients.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation significantly reduced hospital mortality and gram-negative bacteremia in burn patients, but no differences were observed in other outcomes like total burn surface area.
population_specificity: Burn patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of glutamine-enriched feeding in very preterm children on brain development at school age and explore the mediating role of serious neonatal infections.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation was associated with increased white matter, hippocampus, and brain stem volumes at school age, mediated by fewer serious neonatal infections. Higher fractional anisotropy values in the cingulum hippocampal tract were also observed in the glutamine group.
population_specificity: Very preterm children (mean age 8.6 years at follow-up)
study_duration: Administered between day 3 and 30 after birth

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glutamine as a supplemental therapy in reducing severe complications from anticancer treatment and improving patient outcomes.
results_summary: Glutamine was shown to decrease metabolic side effects of cancer treatment and improve patient outcomes, particularly in oncology patients, based on prospective randomized studies. However, optimal dosing and administration routes require further investigation.
population_specificity: Oncology patients, including pediatric cases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review randomized studies on glutamine supplementation in pups, infants, and children to determine its effects on outcomes such as mortality, inflammatory response, and infection control.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation did not reduce mortality or late-onset sepsis in premature infants and critically ill children, though some effects on inflammatory response and infection control were noted. Routine use of glutamine in these populations was not recommended due to lack of significant benefits.
population_specificity: Pups, premature infants, and critically ill children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glutamine in addressing metabolic abnormalities and protein/amino acid requirements in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation is crucial in severe systemic inflammatory responses and that adequate protein/amino acid intake, including glutamine, may be more important than energy requirements for maintaining nitrogen balance and improving outcomes.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients, including those with severe systemic inflammatory response, hypocaloric feeding, and acute renal failure on continuous renal replacement therapy.
effective_dosage: Extra glutamine supplementation is required in severe systemic inflammatory response; protein/amino acids are recommended at 1.3–1.5 g/kg/day for optimal protein-sparing effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore leucine's metabolic influences, including its role in signaling pathways and potential benefits for healthy weight maintenance, with peripheral glutamine synthetic pathways mentioned as a factor.
results_summary: The study highlights leucine's role in stimulating protein synthesis and restraining proteolysis, mediated by glutamine gradients, but notes potential adverse effects like hyperammonemia from overloading glutamine pathways. Animal studies suggest leucine supplementation may counteract high-fat diet effects, but human evidence is still accumulating.
population_specificity: Animal studies and general human metabolic implications (specific human population not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified for glutamine (leucine intakes up to >250 mg · kg(-1) · d(-1) mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of glutamine on glucose metabolism and insulin secretion in boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: Acute glutamine administration transiently increased insulin secretion but had no effect on plasma glucose, HOMA, or whole-body glucose turnover. Long-term glutamine supplementation showed no significant effects on insulin or HOMA.
population_specificity: Prepubertal boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine supplementation reduces mortality and morbidity in young infants with severe gastrointestinal disease.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of two small trials found no statistically significant difference in death risk or invasive infection rates with glutamine supplementation. The data were insufficient to confirm any clinically important benefits.
population_specificity: Infants up to three months old with severe gastrointestinal disease requiring parenteral nutrition for at least 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine supplementation prevents necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in high-risk infants.
results_summary: The study concluded that glutamine supplementation is not recommended for infants at risk for NEC, citing insufficient evidence for its efficacy in preventing the condition.
population_specificity: Extremely low birth weight and extremely preterm infants at risk for NEC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined supplement including L-glutamine could alleviate heroin withdrawal symptoms and improve mood states in detoxified heroin addicts.
results_summary: The study found that the combined supplement significantly improved insomnia, withdrawal scores, and mood symptoms (tension-anxiety, depression-dejection, anger-hostility, fatigue-inertia, and vigor-activity) compared to placebo by day 6.
population_specificity: Detoxified heroin addicts recruited from a treatment center in Wuhan, China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if glutamine supplementation in parenteral nutrition for surgical infants would reduce time to full enteral feeding and decrease sepsis incidence.
results_summary: Glutamine did not reduce time to full enteral feeding or overall sepsis incidence, but it significantly decreased sepsis risk during total parenteral nutrition before the first enteral feed.
population_specificity: Surgical infants less than 3 months old requiring parenteral nutrition.
effective_dosage: 0.6 g per kg per day alanyl-glutamine.
study_duration: Until full enteral feeding was achieved.

study_goal: To determine the effects of glutamine supplementation on mortality and morbidity in preterm infants.
results_summary: Meta-analysis found no statistically significant effect of glutamine supplementation on mortality or major neonatal morbidities, including invasive infection or necrotising enterocolitis. Neurodevelopmental outcomes at 18 to 24 months also showed no significant differences.
population_specificity: Preterm infants from birth to hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of parenteral glutamine supplementation on mortality, infections, and hospital length of stay in critically ill patients and those undergoing major surgery.
results_summary: Parenteral glutamine supplementation was associated with a non-significant 11% reduction in short-term mortality, a significant reduction in infections, and a 2.35-day shorter hospital stay, though results were influenced by one recent trial and potential publication bias.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients and patients undergoing major surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glutamine supplementation in improving outcomes for critically ill and post-surgical patients receiving parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study suggests that parenteral glutamine supplementation, alongside other pharmaconutrients, benefits critically ill and post-surgical patients by potentially reducing complications and improving recovery.
population_specificity: Critically ill and post-surgical patients with gastrointestinal stress or intolerance to enteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of early nutritional support, including glutamine supplementation, in polytrauma patients to mitigate metabolic stress and malnutrition risks.
results_summary: The study suggests that early enteral nutrition with glutamine supplementation provides advantages over other routes and formulas for polytrauma patients, though specific efficacy data on glutamine alone are not detailed. Reduced calorie intake may be considered for obese patients or those with medullary lesions, but evidence is limited.
population_specificity: Polytrauma patients, typically older with higher BMI and greater comorbidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a food supplement containing L-glutamine, along with D-phenylalanine and L-5-hydroxytryptophan, could alleviate alcohol withdrawal symptoms and improve immune function during detoxification therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement significantly reduced psychiatric symptoms (SCL-90-R scores) and increased CD4 lymphocyte counts in the intervention group, but did not affect cortisol levels, liver enzymes, or bilirubin, which improved equally in both groups.
population_specificity: 20 patients with alcohol addiction undergoing detoxification therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term cognitive, motor, and behavioral effects of enteral glutamine supplementation in very preterm and/or very low birth weight children at school age.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation had no significant effects on cognitive, motor, or behavioral outcomes, except for poorer visuomotor abilities in the glutamine group. The study found no differences in IQ, processing speed, attention, working memory, or behavioral outcomes between glutamine and placebo groups.
population_specificity: Very preterm (< 32 weeks of gestation) and/or very low birth weight (< 1500 g) children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific basis for glutamine supplementation in severely ill patients and assess its benefits in inflammatory states.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation was beneficial in burn or trauma patients and more convincingly demonstrated clinical benefits in severe inflammation. The amounts supplemented were in the physiological range, matching the glutamine released by peripheral tissues and utilized by central organs.
population_specificity: Severely ill patients, including burn or trauma patients and those with severe inflammation.
effective_dosage: Amounts approximate the physiological range of glutamine released by peripheral tissues (specific dosage not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of glutamine and omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids on metabolism and functional capacity in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that glutamine and omega-3 fatty acids may have synergistic effects on oxidative metabolism, lipolysis, and inflammation, potentially improving functional capacity in heart failure patients. However, specific results or statistical significance are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure experiencing metabolic abnormalities, inflammation, and muscle atrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether glutamine supplementation could improve glutathione levels and sulfur-containing amino acid metabolism in HIV⁺ patients compared to healthy controls.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation equalized glutathione, glutamine, and glycine levels in HIV⁺ patients to match those of healthy controls, suggesting it may replenish glycine pools to support glutathione synthesis.
population_specificity: HIV⁺ patients (n=12) and healthy controls (n=20), aged 20-59 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of immune-enhancing diets, including glutamine, in improving post-operative recovery by boosting the immune system and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study suggests that glutamine, as part of immune-enhancing diets, may improve immune function, wound healing, and reduce inflammatory markers, contributing to better surgical outcomes.
population_specificity: Surgical patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily supplementation with glutamine, combined with zinc, selenium, and metoclopramide, could reduce nosocomial infection/sepsis in pediatric intensive care patients compared to whey protein.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in time to nosocomial infection/sepsis between the glutamine-containing supplement and whey protein in the overall population. However, a reduction in infection/sepsis rates was observed in the immunocompromised subgroup with the glutamine-containing supplement.
population_specificity: Pediatric intensive care patients (ages 1-17) expected to require >72 hours of invasive care, including a small subset (9%) who were immunocompromised.
effective_dosage: Daily enteral glutamine (exact dosage not specified in abstract) combined with zinc, selenium, and intravenous metoclopramide.
study_duration: Up to 28 days of ICU stay.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether enteral glutamine could protect gut function and reduce metabolic stress in rectal cancer patients undergoing preoperative radiochemotherapy.
results_summary: Glutamine did not reduce the incidence or severity of diarrhea compared to placebo. Insulin levels increased in both groups, while IL-6 levels increased only in the glutamine group, with no significant impact on inflammatory or metabolic activity.
population_specificity: 33 patients with rectal cancer undergoing preoperative radiochemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 30 g/day (0.41 g/kg/day) in three divided doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether glutamine supplementation supports chemoradiotherapy efficacy while reducing tissue toxicity and improving outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation appears to enhance chemoradiotherapy efficacy, reduce tissue toxicity, and improve treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with malnutrition related to anorexia-cachexia syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intravenous glutamine supplementation improves outcomes (SOFA scores and mortality) in ICU patients.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation reduced ICU mortality in the per protocol group but showed no difference in SOFA score changes or 6-month mortality.
population_specificity: ICU patients receiving enteral and/or parenteral nutrition within 72 hours of admission.
effective_dosage: 0.283 g glutamine/kg body weight/24 h as i.v. l-alanyl-l-glutamine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine levels influence the cytoprotective cellular stress response (CSR) in mesothelial cells exposed to peritoneal dialysis fluids (PDF) and whether alanyl-glutamine (Ala-Gln) supplementation could restore an adequate CSR.
results_summary: The study found that physiological glutamine levels resulted in an inadequate CSR and increased cellular damage, while pharmacological doses of Ala-Gln restored cytoprotective processes and reduced damage in mesothelial cells exposed to PDF.
population_specificity: Human mesothelial cells (immortalized cell line MeT-5A and cells derived from peritoneal effluent of uraemic patients).
effective_dosage: 0 mM (depletion), 0.7 mM (physiological), and 8 mM (pharmacological, administered as Ala-Gln).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral glutamine supplementation improves gut integrity and reduces the incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) and septicemia in preterm neonates.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation significantly reduced intestinal permeability (measured by lactulose/mannitol ratio) and lowered the incidence of NEC and septicemia in preterm infants compared to the control group. The effects were statistically significant at multiple time points during the study.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates (gestational age <34 weeks, birth weight <2000 g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of phenylbutyrate administration on glutamine kinetics and nitrogen disposal in healthy and ornithine transcarbamylase-deficient (OTCD) subjects.
results_summary: Phenylbutyrate reduced ureagenesis and the transfer of nitrogen from glutamine to urea without affecting glutamine flux or concentration, suggesting no adverse effects on protein metabolism. BCAA supplementation did not alter glutamine-related outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy controls and partial- or null-OTCD subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of an amino acid supplement containing glutamine on glucose homeostasis, hormonal markers, and inflammation after laparoscopic gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the glutamine-containing supplement had no effect on incretins but may negatively influence glucose kinetics and inflammation, with worsened insulin sensitivity and higher inflammatory markers in the experimental group. Weight loss and other hormonal changes were similar between groups.
population_specificity: 30 patients (96.7% female, age 46.9 ± 8.4 years, BMI 43.3 ± 4.1 kg/m²) undergoing laparoscopic gastric bypass.
effective_dosage: 24 g of supplement (containing glutamine, leucine metabolite, and arginine) twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glutamine supplementation as part of a multimodal perioperative nutritional strategy to improve surgical outcomes.
results_summary: The study suggests that glutamine supplementation, alongside other interventions like preoperative carbohydrate-based drinks and enhanced recovery protocols, may help optimize metabolic function and nutritional status in surgical patients. However, it notes significant heterogeneity and poor design in many nutritional intervention studies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing elective surgery, particularly those at high nutritional risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine supplementation in parenteral nutrition reduces new infections and mortality in critically ill patients.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation showed no significant effect on new infections or mortality, even in patients who received ≥5 days of treatment. Secondary outcomes like length of stay, antibiotic use, and organ failure scores were also unaffected.
population_specificity: Critically ill adults in intensive care or high dependency units with gastrointestinal failure requiring parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of glutamine supplementation in very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants, focusing on morbidity, mortality, and neonatal outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of toxicity from glutamine supplementation, but efficacy results were mixed for a limited number of outcomes. Some authors suggest further research is no longer warranted, while others argue additional studies are needed.
population_specificity: Very-low-birth-weight (VLBW) infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of glutamine in attenuating colitis induced by dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) in mice and its potential as a therapeutic agent for inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: Glutamine levels significantly decreased during the acute phase of colonic inflammation, and supplementation with glutamine attenuated DSS-induced colitis in mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with induced colitis
study_duration: 5 days of DSS administration, followed by intervention duration not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether differences in early nutritional support, including glutamine supplementation, mediated the effect of critical illness on growth and adverse outcomes in extremely premature infants.
results_summary: The study found that less critically ill infants received more nutritional support, had better growth velocities, and fewer adverse outcomes compared to more critically ill infants, with total daily energy intake during the first week mediating these effects. Glutamine's specific effects were not isolated in the abstract.
population_specificity: Extremely premature infants in the NICHD Neonatal Research Network.
study_duration: Nutritional support was assessed over the first 3 weeks of life, with outcomes measured up to 18-22 months corrected age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing a preoperative carbohydrate drink with glutamine or lipid affects gastric emptying and postprandial glucose and insulin responses.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation did not prolong gastric emptying but blunted postprandial glucose and insulin responses without affecting GLP-1 concentrations. The effects were comparable to lipid supplementation.
population_specificity: Ten healthy male volunteers
effective_dosage: 15 g glutamine in a single dose
study_duration: Single administration with measurements over 240 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether an oral supplement containing glutamine (HMB/Glu/Arg) could preserve lean body mass (LBM) and resting metabolic rate (RMR) after laparoscopic gastric bypass (LGB).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight, BMI, LBM, or RMR between the group receiving HMB/Glu/Arg and the control group, suggesting the supplement did not effectively preserve LBM or RMR post-LGB. However, the supplement's consumption did not negatively impact weight loss.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent laparoscopic gastric bypass (80% white, 20% African American, 96.7% women, mean age 46.9±8.4 years, mean BMI 43.3±4.1 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 24 g of HMB/Glu/Arg dissolved in water twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative feeding with a carbohydrate-based drink containing glutamine and antioxidants could improve glycogen reserves, mitochondrial function, and metabolic gene expression in surgical patients.
results_summary: The study found that the glutamine-containing supplement increased liver glycogen reserves, plasma glutamine, and antioxidant concentrations, while reducing muscle PDK4 and Mt1A expression, suggesting a potential mechanism for mitigating postoperative insulin resistance.
population_specificity: 40 patients undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy (20 in the ONS group, 20 in the placebo group).
effective_dosage: 600 mL the evening before surgery (containing 50 g carbohydrate, 15 g glutamine, and antioxidants) and 300 mL 3-4 hours before anesthesia.
study_duration: Short-term (administered the evening before and a few hours before surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of human growth hormone with or without glutamine supplementation for adult patients with short bowel syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that human growth hormone with or without glutamine increased weight, lean body mass, energy absorption, and nitrogen absorption in short bowel syndrome patients, though benefits were often short-lived after therapy cessation. Only patients receiving HGH with glutamine maintained significant parenteral nutrition reductions at 3-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Adult patients with short bowel syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of intravenous glutamine-supplemented TPN on immune states in patients with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
results_summary: Glutamine-added TPN significantly decreased leukocyte and natural killer cell counts, suppressing inflammation, and increased total lymphocyte count and subgroups, though not statistically significant. No significant differences were observed in immune markers or clinical scores between the glutamine and control groups.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether parenteral glutamine supplementation could improve hepatic tolerance in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation reduced serum levels of AST and total bilirubin, indicating improved hepatic function. No deaths occurred, and fewer infants in the glutamine group were withdrawn from the study compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight (VLBW) infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the accuracy of bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) and skinfold thickness (ST) measurements in tracking body composition changes in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients undergoing glutamine supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that BIA more accurately estimated changes in fat-free mass (FFM) and percentage fat mass (%FM) compared to ST when validated against DXA, suggesting BIA is a reliable method for monitoring nutritional status in DMD patients. The abstract does not report specific outcomes related to glutamine's efficacy.
population_specificity: Ambulatory boys aged 3-11 years with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms of immunonutrients, including glutamine, and their immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory benefits in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine, when administered as part of immune-enhancing formulas, reduces infectious outcomes in critically ill patients. It also highlighted the benefits of isolated nutrients like glutamine for immunomodulation and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutamine supplementation alters the expression and functionality of TLR2 and TLR4 in circulating monocytes of trauma patients in the ICU.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation did not significantly alter TLR2 or TLR4 expression or functionality in monocytes, nor did it improve phagocytic ability or cytokine responses to TLR agonists.
population_specificity: Trauma patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether glutamine, alone or in combination with selenium, improves outcomes in critical care settings.
results_summary: The study found insufficient data to confidently recommend glutamine's optimal use, noting weak evidence for parenteral glutamine and weakest for enteral glutamine. Pending results from the SIGNET trial may clarify current ambiguities.
population_specificity: Critical care patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of branched-chain amino acid (BCAA) supplementation, including glutamine production, in addressing hepatic encephalopathy, liver regeneration, and hepatic cachexia in liver disease.
results_summary: BCAA supplementation may improve hepatic encephalopathy by aiding ammonia detoxification and correcting amino acid imbalances. It also supports liver regeneration and nutritional status by enhancing protein synthesis, hepatocyte growth factor secretion, and glutamine production while inhibiting proteolysis.
population_specificity: Patients with various forms of hepatic injury, including liver cirrhosis and hepatic cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an enteral supplement containing glutamine and antioxidants could moderate the immuno-inflammatory response after major gastrointestinal surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the glutamine and antioxidant supplement led to a more pronounced decrease in CRP levels and a reduction in TNF-R75 levels compared to the control group, suggesting a moderating effect on the immuno-inflammatory response post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major gastrointestinal tract surgery (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of glutamine and arginine supplementation, particularly their combined use, on gut barrier function, inflammatory response, and oxidative stress in stressed conditions.
results_summary: Glutamine supplementation reduces morbidity and mortality in critically ill patients and regulates gut barrier function, immuno-inflammatory response, and antioxidant status. Combined administration with arginine showed additive or synergistic effects on gut barrier function and inflammatory response but reduced glutamine's protection against oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients and surgical patients.
interactions: Arginine reduced glutamine's protection against oxidative stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of physical exercise and inactivity on glutamine metabolism and its implications for immunocompetence and health.
results_summary: Strenuous exercise and overtraining reduce glutamine availability, leading to immunodepression, while moderate training improves glutamine availability and health benefits. Physical inactivity also reduces glutamine synthesis, suggesting potential benefits of supplementation.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers and individuals undergoing physical exercise or inactivity (e.g., bed rest).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of glutamine supplementation in tumor-bearing hosts and assess its safety and efficacy in clinical oncology.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation improves host metabolism and clinical outcomes in cancer patients without increasing tumor growth, and it can mitigate gastrointestinal toxicity from treatments like chemotherapy and radiation. Potential mechanisms include immune support, mucosal integrity maintenance, and enhanced glutathione synthesis.
population_specificity: Cancer patients, particularly those undergoing high-dose chemotherapy, radiation, or bone marrow transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of glutamine on systemic inflammatory response, morbidity, and mortality after esophagectomy.
results_summary: The study found that glutamine supplementation had no significant influence on morbidity, mortality, or postoperative inflammatory response after esophagectomy. Inflammatory markers and clinical outcomes were similar between the glutamine and control groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing esophagectomy.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g/kg as continuous infusion for 6 hours, administered for 3 days prior to and 7 days following surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanisms by which NAC and its enantiomer d-NAC inhibit ferroptosis, particularly their role as direct reducing substrates for GPX4.
results_summary: The study found that NAC and d-NAC rapidly replenish intracellular cysteine and act as direct reducing substrates for GPX4, counteracting lipid peroxidation and preventing ferroptosis independently of glutathione biosynthesis or other pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro (cell-based research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biological effects of TiO2 nanoparticles, including their impact on glutathione metabolism, in neural cells.
results_summary: The study found that TiO2 nanoparticles caused a significant increase in glutathione levels in SH-SY5Y cells, linked with increased glutamate-cysteine ligase expression, but also observed decreased mitochondrial respiration without glutathione depletion.
population_specificity: Neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different sulfur sources (FeS2 and H2SO4) influence cadmium (Cd) uptake, transfer, accumulation, and the regulation of physiological responses, including glutathione (GSH) and cysteine (Cys) levels, in pepper plants under Cd stress.
results_summary: Both sulfur sources (FeS2 and H2SO4) enhanced pepper growth and increased GSH and Cys levels, with FeS2 showing a more pronounced reduction in Cd content. GSH levels increased significantly under high Cd stress, particularly in leaves, while Cys was highest in fruits.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum spp., 'Z2' line) grown in yellow soil under controlled pot conditions.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg FeS2 and varying Cd concentrations (e.g., 1.5 mg/kg Cd).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the G6PD/glutathione-dependent pathway in PSNPs-induced striatal neurodegeneration and whether luteolin (LUT) could mitigate these effects.
results_summary: The study found that PSNPs disrupted the G6PD/glutathione-dependent pathway, leading to oxidative dysregulation and ferroptosis, while LUT alleviated these effects by targeting the same pathway.
population_specificity: Mouse model (in vivo and in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs), specifically EpGST1, in conferring herbicide resistance in Echinochloa phyllopogon.
results_summary: The study found that EpGST1 enhances herbicide metabolism, significantly increasing resistance to penoxsulam in both Arabidopsis and rice, while also boosting antioxidant enzyme activities and reducing oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Echinochloa phyllopogon (a weed), Arabidopsis, and rice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of CHAC1 in kidney disease by investigating its impact on glutathione degradation and ferroptosis.
results_summary: The study found that reduced CHAC1 expression increased glutathione levels, decreased lipid peroxidation, improved cell viability, and protected against ferroptosis in kidney disease models. Higher CHAC1 protein correlated with ferroptosis-related protein abundance in kidney disease patients.
population_specificity: Mice and human kidney biopsies (patients with kidney disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) in detoxification, disease pathogenesis, and potential therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that GSTs play a critical role in detoxifying harmful compounds and maintaining cellular homeostasis, but dysregulation can contribute to diseases like cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and chronic inflammation. Polymorphisms in GSTs may lead to toxic metabolite accumulation and chemoresistance, prompting the development of targeted inhibitors.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health implications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how oncogenic events, specifically TERT and FOXO1, regulate glutathione (GSH) biosynthesis in cancer models, particularly glioblastoma (GBM), and explore potential therapeutic vulnerabilities.
results_summary: The study found that TERT upregulates GSH biosynthesis via FOXO1 and GCLC, and inhibiting GCLC with BSO reduces GSH synthesis but drives compensatory pyrimidine biosynthesis. Combining BSO with the glutamine antagonist JHU-083 was synthetically lethal in GBM models, significantly extending survival in mice.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (GBM) cancer models, including in vitro and in vivo (mice with intracranial xenografts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if amustaline/glutathione pathogen-reduced (PR) RBCs could be effectively tracked in vivo using flow cytometry for RBC surface acridine, comparing its sensitivity to biotin labeling.
results_summary: The study found that acridine-labeled PR-RBCs had similar survival kinetics as biotin-labeled RBCs, with detectable acridine levels persisting for 16 weeks. PR-RBCs showed a 9.3% decrease in mean predicted lifespan compared to Pre-PR-RBCs but had similar 24-hour post-transfusion recoveries and half-lives.
population_specificity: Sickle cell disease (SCD) patients (n=6) on chronic transfusion therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified for glutathione; biotin doses were 2 μg/mL, 6 μg/mL, and 18 μg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reduced glutathione (GSH) could protect against doxorubicin (DOX)-induced cardiotoxicity by modulating oxidative stress and inflammation in a mice model.
results_summary: GSH treatment improved survival rates, reduced weight loss, restored cardiac function markers, suppressed oxidative stress and inflammation, modulated gene expression, and decreased histopathological damage in mice exposed to DOX.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exogenous glutathione (GSH) administration could protect against diesel exhaust (DE)-induced lung epithelial disruption, oxidative stress, and inflammation.
results_summary: GSH administration restored antioxidant defenses, mitigated ferroptosis, reduced lipid peroxidation, preserved lung epithelial cell survival, and improved tight junction integrity in DE-exposed mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice
effective_dosage: Administered intranasally on alternate days (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanosystem that enhances chemodynamic therapy (CDT) efficacy by leveraging tumor microenvironment-responsive free radical generation and glutathione (GSH) exhaustion.
results_summary: The study found that the nanosystem effectively depleted GSH, triggered free radical generation, and amplified oxidative stress, leading to significant cancer cell death (30% lower viability in treated cells). The concurrent depletion of GSH and induction of lipid peroxidation weakened cancer cells' anti-oxidative defenses.
population_specificity: 4T1 cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of glutathione amino acid precursors (GAP) against pollutant-induced oxidative stress, metabolic changes, and hyperpigmentation in skin keratinocytes and pigmented skin models.
results_summary: GAP treatment improved glutathione homeostasis, reduced reactive pollutant metabolites, partially reversed metabolic and transcriptomic alterations, decreased DNA damage, and prevented hyperpigmentation in skin models exposed to pollutants.
population_specificity: Normal human epidermal keratinocytes (NHEKs) and reconstructed pigmented skin equivalent models (pLSE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify which glutathione S-transferase (GST) isozymes play a key role in detoxifying Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) in chickens.
results_summary: Overexpression of GSTA2X, GSTA3, GSTT1L, GSTZ1-1, and GSTZ1-2 increased cell viability, reduced oxidative stress and DNA damage, and enhanced AFBO-GSH production, with GSTA2X showing the best detoxification effects.
population_specificity: Chicken Leghorn male hepatoma (LMH) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of glutathione S-transferase gene BrGSTF12 in anthocyanin transport and accumulation in Zicaitai under light induction.
results_summary: The study found that BrGSTF12 expression correlated with anthocyanin content and was functionally involved in anthocyanin transport, as demonstrated by complementation in Arabidopsis mutants. BrMYB114 was also identified as a trans-activator of BrGSTF12, enhancing anthocyanin accumulation.
population_specificity: Zicaitai (Brassica rapa var. purpuraria) plants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of GPX4 in NSCLC and assess its potential as a therapeutic target by modulating ferroptosis and chemotherapy sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that GPX4 influences NSCLC progression by regulating multiple signaling pathways, and blocking GPX4 triggers ferroptosis and enhances chemotherapy sensitivity, making it a promising therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients or models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile the strategic role of glutathione (GSH) in cancer cells and explore the potential of nanotherapeutics for GSH depletion to target various forms of programmed cell death.
results_summary: The study highlights glutathione's paradoxical role in cancer, where elevated intracellular GSH levels protect cancer cells from oxidative stress, and discusses nanotherapeutics as a promising approach to deplete GSH and enhance the efficacy of therapies like chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and novel interventions such as chemodynamic therapy and photodynamic therapy.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro/in vivo context, not specified for human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the multifaceted role of glutathione (GSH) in ferroptosis and its implications for cancer biology and therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that GSH plays a critical role in maintaining redox balance, mitigating oxidative stress, and regulating ferroptosis by serving as a cofactor for GPX4. It also highlighted GSH's influence on key oncogenic and tumor-suppressive pathways, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target in cancer.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or animal models, not explicitly specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of glutathione (GSH) metabolism in Chlamydia pneumoniae growth and replication in THP-1 macrophages and A549 epithelial cells.
results_summary: Depletion of cellular GSH pools decreased C. pneumoniae replication, but only when constituent amino acids were also sequestered. C. pneumoniae infection upregulated both GSH biosynthesis and degradation genes, with PERK phosphorylation playing a key role in this regulation.
population_specificity: THP-1 macrophages and A549 epithelial cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dysregulated glutathione (GSH) metabolism contributes to NK cell dysfunction in acute leukemia and if GSH supplementation could restore NK cell function.
results_summary: The study found that NK cells from acute leukemia patients had reduced GSH levels, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction and impaired cytotoxicity. Supplementation with glutathione reduced ethyl ester (GSHEE) restored GSH levels, improved mitochondrial activity, and enhanced NK cell function and proliferation.
population_specificity: Patients with acute leukemia (AL-NK cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate glutathione's potential as a therapeutic intervention for NAFLD by assessing its effects on oxidative stress markers and liver function.
results_summary: The study found consistent improvements in ALT levels and reductions in oxidative stress markers like 8-OHdG, suggesting glutathione's potential benefits for NAFLD patients. However, small sample sizes and inconsistent protocols limit the generalizability of these findings.
population_specificity: Human subjects with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Tithonia diversifolia zinc oxide nanoparticle emulsion (TDNP) in mitigating diabetic nephropathy by enhancing antioxidant mechanisms, including glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity.
results_summary: TDNP treatment significantly increased glutathione peroxidase (GPx) levels, reduced oxidative stress markers, and improved glucose metabolism and kidney function in diabetic nephropathy rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetic nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the multifaceted roles of glutathione (GSH) in physiological contexts, its coordination capabilities in nanomaterials, and its potential biomedical applications.
results_summary: The study found that GSH's unique structural features enable its use as a protective ligand and reducing agent in nanomaterials, enhancing photoluminescence properties and biocompatibility for applications in bio-sensing, bio-imaging, and anti-cancer therapies.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on molecular and nanomaterial applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize a novel fosfomycin resistance gene (fosA13) in M. morganii and explore its potential resistance mechanisms.
results_summary: The study identified a new chromosomal fosfomycin resistance gene (fosA13) in M. morganii, which showed effective inactivation of fosfomycin and shared 55.6% amino acid homology with FosA. The isolate also exhibited resistance to multiple antibiotic classes, suggesting uncharacterized resistance mechanisms.
population_specificity: Bacterial isolates (M. morganii DW0548) from poultry and livestock in Wenzhou, China.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (study focused on genetic and enzymatic characterization).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of iron atomically dispersed nanoparticles (Fe-N-C) as sonosensitizers in enhancing reactive oxygen species (ROS)-based therapies by overcoming tumor microenvironment (TME) limitations, including glutathione (GSH) depletion.
results_summary: Fe-N-C nanoparticles demonstrated highly efficient ROS generation, GSH depletion, and induced tumor cell apoptosis and ferroptosis, showing superior tumor specificity in sonodynamic therapy (SDT).
population_specificity: Tumor microenvironment (TME) in the context of cancer therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel multimodal detection method for Glutathione (GSH) using a MOF@COF composite to facilitate disease diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: The study successfully synthesized a core-shell material (UiO@TBTA) that enabled sensitive ratiometric fluorescence and colorimetric detection of GSH, with detection ranges of 0.1-7 μM and 1-200 μM, respectively. Machine learning models were also constructed to accurately determine GSH concentrations from fluorescence images and color photographs.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel nanocomposite could enhance ferroptosis in cancer cells by depleting glutathione (GSH) and generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
results_summary: The study found that the MnO2R@FePDA-cRGD nanocomposite effectively depleted intracellular GSH and generated significant ROS, leading to enhanced ferroptosis and tumor growth inhibition in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Cancer cells and tumor models (in vitro and in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel nanoparticle system (PDOX-AP/cRGD-NPs) incorporating glutathione (GSH)-responsive polymers for targeted drug delivery and combination chemotherapy in glioblastoma treatment.
results_summary: The study found that PDOX-AP/cRGD-NPs effectively penetrated the blood-brain barrier, targeted brain tumors, and demonstrated controlled drug release, leading to reduced tumor cell viability, increased apoptosis, and extended survival in glioma models.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma cell lines (GL-261, U87-MG, LN-229) and in vivo glioma models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutathione-protected Au22 nanoclusters (GSH-Au22 NCs) could mitigate brain damage from hypoxic-ischemic injury in rats and oxygen-glucose deprivation in cortical neurons, while exploring the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: GSH-Au22 NCs improved cell activity, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress in vitro, and in vivo, they decreased cerebral infarction, enhanced tissue recovery, and improved long-term learning and memory by modulating the Sirt3/SOD2 pathway.
population_specificity: Rats with hypoxic-ischemic brain injury and cortical primary neurons exposed to oxygen-glucose deprivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the levels of glutathione (GSH) as an antioxidant marker in people living with HIV (PLWH) co-infected with human coronaviruses (hCoVs) compared to mono-infected and HIV-negative controls.
results_summary: Reduced GSH levels were significantly lower in HIV+/hCoVs+ individuals compared to HIV+/hCoVs- but higher than in HIV-/hCoVs- controls. The study also found associations between oxidative stress markers (MDA and GSH) and ART regimens/duration.
population_specificity: 300 PLWH in Ghana, divided into HIV+/hCoVs+, HIV+/hCoVs-, and HIV-/hCoVs- groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in glutathione levels (T-GSH, GSSG, GSH, and GSH/GSSG ratio) in schizophrenia patients before and after ECT and their association with clinical symptoms.
results_summary: Schizophrenia patients had lower baseline GSSG levels and higher GSH/GSSG ratios compared to healthy controls. ECT increased GSSG levels and decreased GSH/GSSG ratios in treatment responders, with baseline glutathione metrics predictive of clinical improvement.
population_specificity: 110 patients with acute relapse of schizophrenia and 55 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutathione (GSH) could mitigate cadmium (Cd)-induced stress in Pogostemon cablin (patchouli) by examining physiological and enzymatic responses.
results_summary: GSH increased chlorophyll and carotenoid levels by approximately 20% compared to other groups and improved antioxidant enzyme activity. It mitigated Cd stress by influencing glycerophospholipid metabolism and flavonoid biosynthesis, reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS).
population_specificity: Pogostemon cablin (patchouli) plants under cadmium stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the detoxification and metabolic mechanisms of tea saponin (TS) in Pomacea canaliculata, focusing on the role of glutathione S-transferases (GSTs) and monoamine oxidase (MAO).
results_summary: The study found that TS exhibited dose- and time-dependent toxicity in P. canaliculata, with increased GST and MAO activities and corresponding gene expression levels, suggesting their involvement in detoxification.
population_specificity: Pomacea canaliculata (a species of snail)
effective_dosage: LC50 values were 6.12, 9.03, and 9.35 mg/L for small, medium, and large snails after 24 h exposure.
study_duration: Exposure durations ranged from 24 h to 29.85 h depending on snail size and TS concentration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether glutathione (GSH) enhances adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stem cell (ADSC) engraftment efficiency by targeting the TGFβ/SMAD3/NOX4 pathway in liver fibrotic mice.
results_summary: GSH significantly improved ADSC engraftment efficiency by reducing ROS generation and inhibiting the TGFβ/SMAD3/NOX4 pathway, enhancing therapeutic efficacy in liver fibrotic mice. The effect was abolished when combined with STX or SIS3.
population_specificity: Liver fibrotic male mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether GST gene polymorphisms (GSTM1, GSTT1, GSTP1) are associated with recurrent pregnancy loss in the Turkish population.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant association between the GSTT1 null genotype and recurrent pregnancy loss, but no significant correlation with GSTM1 or GSTP1 polymorphisms. The GSTM1-null genotype showed a substantial increase in risk for recurrent pregnancy loss.
population_specificity: Turkish women with recurrent pregnancy loss (107 patients) and a control group of 107 individuals with successful births and no miscarriage history.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the roles of glutathione synthesis (GshAB) and transport (GshT) in Streptococcus suis pathogenesis and oxidative stress resistance.
results_summary: Glutathione treatment increased oxidative stress tolerance in S. suis. Deletion of gshAB or gshT reduced intracellular glutathione levels, oxidative stress resistance, phagocytic resistance, and virulence in mouse models.
population_specificity: Streptococcus suis (bacterial pathogen) and mouse models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the catalytic efficiency of a multi-enzymatic nanozyme for glutathione (GSH) detection and its potential to enhance ROS generation and deplete GSH in tumor microenvironments.
results_summary: The study demonstrated rapid quantitative detection of GSH with a low detection limit (0.062 μM) and showed that the nanozyme could simultaneously enhance ROS production and deplete GSH, inducing tumor cell apoptosis.
population_specificity: Tumor microenvironment (in vitro or preclinical context, not specified for human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified for GSH; detection range was 5-60 μM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the oxidative damage and toxic effects of diamide insecticides (cyantraniliprole and broflanilide) on plants using AtGSTF8 as a biomarker.
results_summary: Cyantraniliprole caused more detrimental impacts on plant growth and significantly upregulated AtGSTF8 gene expression compared to broflanilide. Both insecticides reduced glutathione S-transferase activities in AtGSTF8, with cyantraniliprole showing stronger binding affinity and adverse structural effects.
population_specificity: Plant seedlings (specific species not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of chlorophyllin (an antioxidant) and its combination with docetaxel on metastatic processes in triple-negative breast cancer, focusing on GSTP1 inhibition.
results_summary: Combined chlorophyllin and docetaxel treatment significantly inhibited cell migration in vitro and reduced total gelatinase activity in vivo, with a non-significant reduction in liver micrometastases.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer (4T1 cell line and metastatic animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how integrating glutathione depletion with porphyrin-based metal-organic frameworks could enhance photodynamic therapy efficacy in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that elevated glutathione levels in cancer cells reduce oxidative stress from photodynamic therapy, protecting cells. Functionalized nanoplatforms depleting glutathione improved therapy efficacy and restored fluorescence imaging capabilities.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or preclinical models, not specified for human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop polymeric hydrogels incorporating glutathione (GHS) to support the treatment of acne vulgaris and improve skin health.
results_summary: The study found that glutathione-containing hydrogels exhibited potential as carriers for active substances, contributing positively to acne treatment and skin health, with bioactivity confirmed in simulated physiological fluids and no cytotoxic effects on L929 cells.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using mouse fibroblast cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) progression and its interaction with obesity and oxidative stress.
results_summary: GPX4 suppression increased TNBC cell death in vitro and reduced tumor burden and metastasis in obese mice, particularly when combined with chemotherapy. Antioxidants mitigated the cytotoxic effects of GPX4 inhibition.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (TNBC cells and obese mice).
interactions: Mentioned interaction with chemotherapy (carboplatin) but not immunotherapy (anti-CTLA4 plus anti-PD1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of glutathione (GSH) depletion on the immune response and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M.tb) burden in the liver and spleen during extrapulmonary tuberculosis (EPTB).
results_summary: GSH depletion led to increased M.tb growth in the liver and spleen, impaired granulomatous response, elevated oxidative stress markers (MDA), and altered cytokine profiles (reduced IL-12 and IL-17, increased IFN-γ, TNF-α, and TGF-β).
population_specificity: Wild-type (WT) C57BL/6 mice infected with M.tb and treated with diethyl maleate (DEM) to induce GSH depletion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if priming mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) with human platelet lysate (hPL) to increase glutathione levels could improve MSC function and suppress osteoarthritis (OA) progression via paracrine rejuvenation.
results_summary: Priming MSCs with hPL increased cellular glutathione levels, enhancing MSC function and suppressing OA progression by targeting senescent chondrocytes via secreted IGF2, which activated autophagy. The study demonstrated that IGF2 knockdown abolished therapeutic efficacy, confirming its role in paracrine rejuvenation.
population_specificity: Rabbit OA model and in vitro OA chondrocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous cystine influences glutathione metabolism and its role in enhancing the efficacy of gentamicin against drug-resistant Salmonella.
results_summary: Exogenous cystine activated the glutathione pathway, altered the GSH/GSSG ratio, and increased Fe2+ and ROS levels, leading to redox imbalance and enhanced susceptibility of Salmonella to gentamicin.
population_specificity: Salmonella enterica Typhimurium (ATCC 14028) and other clinically resistant Salmonella serotypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of glutathione-s-transferase (GST) in the detoxification process of imazethapyr in lentil crops at the seedling stage.
results_summary: The study found that GST activity increased progressively with higher doses of imazethapyr, indicating its role in detoxification. The Vmax of GST varied from 35.59-83.33 μmol of CDNB across different imazethapyr doses, suggesting enhanced enzymatic activity under herbicide stress.
population_specificity: Lentil crops at the seedling stage.
effective_dosage: Imazethapyr doses of 0.5 RFD, 1 RFD, 1.25 RFD, 1.5 RFD, and 2 RFD.
study_duration: Sampling periods from 0 HBT to 120 HAT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether targeting the Nrf2 signaling pathway could enhance the glutathione-dependent detoxification capabilities of choroid plexuses in neonatal rats.
results_summary: The study found that dimethylfumarate treatment triggered Nrf2 nuclear translocation, increased glutathione-S-transferase (GST) activity in choroid plexus, and reduced the permeation of a toxicant, demonstrating enhanced detoxification. Nrf2 knockout rats showed reduced efficacy of dimethylfumarate, confirming its action primarily through the Nrf2 pathway.
population_specificity: Neonatal rat pups

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether reducing intracellular glutathione (GSH) levels could enhance the efficacy of chemodynamic therapy (CDT) in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that a novel HDAC-inhibiting nanoprodrug could deplete GSH levels in tumor cells, thereby enhancing oxidative damage and improving CDT efficacy. The approach involved ROS-triggered release of compounds to upregulate ROS and GSH-responsive release of HDAC inhibitors to suppress GSH synthesis.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro or preclinical model, not specified for human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of micro-environmental reducing status, particularly glutathione (GSH), in regulating mutp53 stability and its spatially heterogeneous accumulation in cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that higher reducibility (linked to GSH levels) correlated with increased mutp53 accumulation, particularly in the nucleus. Supplementing GSH exacerbated mutp53 accumulation, while consuming GSH depleted it, suggesting GSH's role in stabilizing mutp53 via inhibition of glutathionylation and subsequent degradation.
population_specificity: Patient-derived tumor tissues, mutp53-expressing cancer cell lines, and p53-mutated cell-derived xenografts in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the mechanism of glutathione S-transferase (GST) in drug resistance development and summarize progress in GST imaging detection.
results_summary: The study found that GST plays a key role in cellular detoxification and is associated with resistance to chemotherapeutic drugs, pesticides, herbicides, and antibiotics. It also reviewed the types and research progress of organic small molecule fluorescence probes for GST imaging detection.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on organisms, including potential applications in environmental protection and tumor therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glutathione and thioredoxin systems in regulating redox homeostasis and their potential as therapeutic targets for glioblastoma progression.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that glutathione and thioredoxin systems play a critical role in counteracting reactive oxygen species in glioblastoma cells, suggesting their involvement in cancer progression, but does not provide specific efficacy outcomes.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma patients (theoretical or review-based, not a clinical trial population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of glutathione in oxidative stress detoxification and antibiotic susceptibility in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
results_summary: Glutathione-deficient mutant strains of P. aeruginosa showed increased susceptibility to oxidative stress (hydrogen peroxide and superoxide) and antibiotics (2- to fourfold more susceptible than the parental strain), indicating glutathione's crucial role in detoxification and intrinsic antibiotic resistance. Genetic complementation restored resistance, confirming glutathione's protective function.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1 (bacterial strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of glutathione, both alone and in combination with vitamin C and N-acetylcysteine, for improving behavior and biologic measures in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in behavioral or biologic measures between treatment groups. Small improvements observed were likely due to placebo effects or reduced anxiety from the study routine. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-16 years with ASD and severe behavior disorders.
effective_dosage: Weekly intravenous injections (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 8 weeks per intervention phase, with a 1-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a GSH-responsive nano-prodrug for targeted co-delivery of doxorubicin and glycyrrhetinic acid to enhance cancer therapy.
results_summary: The GSH-responsive nano-prodrug demonstrated effective intracellular release of doxorubicin in tumor cells, leading to enhanced therapeutic efficacy in mouse models of liver and breast cancer. The high GSH levels in the cytoplasm triggered drug release, improving sensitivity to treatment.
population_specificity: Mouse models of liver cancer and breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of GSTM2 in mediating NEFA-induced hepatic inflammation in dairy cows with severe fatty liver.
results_summary: The study found that GSTM2 mitigates NEFA-induced hepatic inflammation, with overexpression reducing inflammatory signals and silencing exacerbating them.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (healthy and those with severe fatty liver) and hepatocytes from healthy calves.
effective_dosage: NEFA concentrations of 0.6, 1.2, and 2.4 mM for in vitro studies.
study_duration: In vitro treatments lasted up to 18 hours; in vivo comparisons were based on single-time-point sampling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of lncRNAs induced by endophyte infection in rice seedlings under Pb stress, particularly focusing on glutathione metabolism.
results_summary: Endophyte infection increased glutathione content, glutathione S-transferase, and glutathione reductase activities in rice seedlings under Pb stress, suggesting enhanced glutathione metabolism as a response mechanism.
population_specificity: Rice seedlings (Oryza sativa) infected and uninfected with endophyte under Pb stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biomarker-responsive AuNR-based Janus nanoprobe that utilizes glutathione (GSH) in the tumor microenvironment to trigger chemodynamic treatment and enhance imaging and radiosensitization.
results_summary: The study found that highly expressed GSH in tumors degrades MnO2, triggering chemodynamic treatment, while also contributing to the aggregation of AuNRs, which amplifies photoacoustic signals and enhances radiosensitization.
population_specificity: Tumor microenvironment (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of itaconate (IA) and its derivative 4-octyl itaconate (OI) on melanoma, particularly focusing on their impact on glutathione metabolism and cancer cell proliferation.
results_summary: OI treatment significantly suppressed melanoma cell proliferation by disrupting glutathione metabolism, leading to decreased intracellular glutathione levels, increased reactive oxygen species, DNA damage, and cellular senescence. Minimal effects were observed in melanocytes and normal tissues.
population_specificity: Melanoma cells (B16 cells) and tumor transplants in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential porphyrin-based inhibitors of glutathione transferases in schistosomes to develop new anthelmintic drugs.
results_summary: Computational modeling identified different lead compounds (CID: 122690402, CID: 137797052 for 26-kDa GST; CID: 70415734, CID: 69301914 for 28-kDa GST) depending on the protein structure conformation used, highlighting the importance of protein dynamics in drug design.
population_specificity: Schistosoma parasites (specifically Schistosoma japonicum and Schistosoma haematobium).

study_goal: To evaluate the therapeutic impact of reduced glutathione combined with entecavir on liver function, fibrosis, and HBV-DNA clearance in chronic hepatitis B patients.
results_summary: The combination of reduced glutathione and entecavir significantly improved liver function markers, reduced liver fibrosis, and enhanced HBV-DNA clearance compared to entecavir alone, with no significant increase in adverse reactions.
population_specificity: 90 patients diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B.
effective_dosage: Not specified for glutathione (entecavir dosage: 0.5 mg/time, once daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of glutathione (GSH) in mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress in fibroblasts from patients with CMT4B3, a subtype of Charcot Marie Tooth disease.
results_summary: The study found that CMT4B3-associated mutations led to lower GSH levels, making cells more vulnerable to oxidative stress. Treatment with hydroperoxide increased cell death rates in CMT patients' fibroblasts compared to controls, highlighting the importance of GSH in mitigating oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Fibroblasts from patients with autosomal recessive, predominantly demyelinating CMT4B3 subtype.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of glutathione downregulation in enhancing apoptosis of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) cells via a novel drug delivery system.
results_summary: The study found that downregulation of glutathione, along with activation of the CCND2 signaling pathway, contributed to OSCC cell death, demonstrating high efficacy in limiting cell proliferation and migration.
population_specificity: Oral squamous cell carcinoma (HSC-3 & SCC-25 cell lines) and xenograft nude mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to uncover mechanisms of rewired glutathione (GSH) metabolism in platinum-resistant cancers and identify potential therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance.
results_summary: The study found that lncRNA GDIL promotes GSH accumulation by inhibiting its degradation, contributing to platinum resistance in colorectal and ovarian cancers. Suppressing GDIL restored drug sensitivity and delayed resistance in cell lines and xenografts.
population_specificity: Platinum-resistant colorectal cancer (CRC) and ovarian cancer cells, including patient-derived xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety of S-Acetyl Glutathione (SAG) supplementation through various toxicity studies to support its use in foods or dietary supplements.
results_summary: The study found no genotoxic, mutagenic, or adverse effects from SAG supplementation, with a NOAEL of 1500 mg/kg/day. Mild, non-adverse increases in organ weights were observed but were within historical control ranges.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and animal models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how UDCA affects cystine uptake and glutathione (GSH) synthesis, and its potential antitumor effects in retroperitoneal liposarcoma (RLPS).
results_summary: UDCA was found to inhibit cystine uptake via SLC7A11, impairing GSH synthesis and leading to ROS accumulation and mitochondrial oxidative damage. It also enhanced the effects of various antitumor agents, suggesting a potential role in combination therapies for RLPS and other cancers.
population_specificity: Retroperitoneal liposarcoma (RLPS) patients and healthy subjects (comparison).
interactions: Enhanced effects of ferroptosis inducers (Erastin, RSL3), MDM2 inhibitors (Nutlin 3a, RG7112), CDK4 inhibitor (Abemaciclib), and glutaminase inhibitor (CB839).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a glutathione-responsive nanoparticle system for targeted delivery of chemotherapy and antisense oligonucleotides to cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that glutathione-responsive nanoparticles effectively delivered camptothecin and antisense oligonucleotides into cancer cells, resulting in enhanced cytotoxicity due to synergistic effects. High intracellular glutathione levels triggered drug release, demonstrating targeted efficacy.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how glutathione (GSH) inhibits TRPM7-mediated oxidative stress and apoptosis in glioblastoma (DBTRG-05MG) cells when combined with cisplatin.
results_summary: GSH reduced cisplatin-induced increases in cytosolic free Ca2+, ROS, apoptosis, and cell death while improving cell viability and GSH concentrations in DBTRG-05MG cells. The combination of GSH with cisplatin showed protective effects against oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Glioblastoma (DBTRG-05MG) cells in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a biomimetic nanoreactor could enhance chemodynamic therapy (CDT) efficacy in glioma by depleting glutathione (GSH) and elevating tumor acidity.
results_summary: The study found that the nanoreactor effectively depleted GSH and accelerated the Fenton reaction, improving CDT efficacy in glioma. Both in vitro and in vivo experiments demonstrated the potential of this strategy for targeted tumor therapy.
population_specificity: Glioma (tumor model, not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of an orally bioavailable prodrug of ψ-GSH (pro-ψ-GSH) in reversing cognitive decline and related pathologies in a transgenic Alzheimer's disease mouse model.
results_summary: Chronic oral dosing of pro-ψ-GSH effectively reversed cognitive decline, reduced amyloid pathology, glycation stress, neuroinflammation, and neurodegeneration in APP/PS1 mice, mirroring the effects of the parent drug. Metabolomic analysis identified key biomarkers linked to the reversal of AD-related metabolic dysregulation.
population_specificity: Transgenic APP/PS1 Alzheimer's disease mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of glutathione (GSH) in treating postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) by reviewing existing literature on neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and related mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests that GSH may be a potential treatment for POCD, but specific and targeted therapies remain sparse, emphasizing the need for further research to better understand its effects.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD), particularly older individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between glutathione transferases (GSTs) genetic variations and the response to azathioprine (AZA) in autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) patients.
results_summary: GSTM1 and GSTT1 copy number variations were associated with AZA treatment response in AIH, with GSTM1 deletion linked to liver transaminase levels. No genetic variants affected thiopurine metabolite concentrations, suggesting non-enzymatic mechanisms for GSTs in AZA efficacy.
population_specificity: 131 AIH patients on AZA and 283 individuals from a Swedish background population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of Glutathione (GSH) in improving treatment outcomes for HIV-TB co-infection, particularly in the CNS, by enhancing antibiotic efficacy, reducing inflammation, and mitigating immune dysfunction.
results_summary: Preclinical studies showed GSH improved macrophage antimicrobial function, reduced oxidative stress, and limited M.tb growth. Clinical studies indicated increased TH1 cytokine production, reduced inflammatory markers, and improved CD4+ T cell counts in HIV-M.tb co-infected patients, with NAC (a GSH precursor) enhancing TB antibiotic efficacy and reducing toxicity.
population_specificity: HIV and tuberculosis (TB) co-infected patients, with emphasis on CNS involvement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of ultrasmall Mn3O4 nanoparticles for integrated tumor MRI imaging and therapy, focusing on their interaction with glutathione (GSH) in the tumor microenvironment.
results_summary: The study found that Mn3O4 nanoparticles react with high-level GSH in tumors, enabling responsive and enhanced MRI imaging for accurate diagnosis, while also inducing ferroptosis in tumor cells, indicating therapeutic potential.
population_specificity: Tumor cells and in vivo models (specific human population not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of microsomal glutathione transferase 1 (MGST1) in cisplatin (DDP) resistance in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells and its mechanism involving ferroptosis.
results_summary: The study found that high MGST1 expression contributed to DDP resistance by inhibiting ALOX5-induced ferroptosis. Silencing MGST1 sensitized NSCLC cells to DDP therapy both in vitro and in vivo by promoting ferroptosis.
population_specificity: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients and DDP-resistant NSCLC cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a nanodrug (CSAA/Fe@PPI) that synergistically promotes ferroptosis in cancer cells by increasing intracellular labile iron, exacerbating lipid peroxidation, and overcoming the glutathione (GSH)-dependent defense system.
results_summary: The nanodrug effectively scavenges intracellular GSH, elevates labile iron levels, induces ROS burst, and suppresses GPX4 activity, leading to enhanced ferroptotic antitumor efficacy. The study demonstrated improved ferroptosis-based anti-cancer treatment through multiple intervention routes.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or preclinical model, not specified for human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a platelet membrane biomimetic nanomedicine (PMD) could deplete intracellular glutathione (GSH) to enhance tumor radioimmunotherapy.
