results_summary: The study found that PMD induced dual GSH depletion, inhibited glycolysis, and enhanced radioimmunotherapy, leading to suppressed tumor growth and increased immune response markers like mature dendritic cells and CD8+ T cells.
population_specificity: Mice with bilateral tumors (in vivo model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of IDH2-regulated glutathione metabolism in cetuximab resistance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).
results_summary: The study found that IDH2 regulated glutathione metabolism, contributing to cetuximab resistance in HNSCC. IDH2 knockdown reduced GSH levels and GPX4 expression while increasing lipid ROS levels, enhancing cetuximab sensitivity in resistant cells.
population_specificity: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) cell lines (FaDu and FaDu-CR) and nude mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a glutathione-responsive nanogel platform for efficient and controlled mRNA delivery, optimizing properties for binding and intracellular release.
results_summary: The nanogels demonstrated high encapsulation (89.3%) and loading (10.7%) efficiencies, outperformed commercial transfection reagents, and enabled targeted mRNA delivery across multiple cell lines, including difficult-to-transfect ones. Enhanced cellular uptake and endosomal escape were observed, likely due to interactions with cell surface thiols.
population_specificity: In vitro cell lines (including traditionally difficult-to-transfect lines)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether curcumin nanocrystals (Cur-NCs) could reduce ferroptosis in high-glucose-induced renal damage, potentially offering a treatment for diabetic nephropathy.
results_summary: Cur-NCs attenuated high-glucose-induced ferroptosis by recovering GPX4 levels, reducing lipid ROS, and inhibiting renal damage in diabetic nephropathy models. The effects were partially inhibited by erastin, suggesting ferroptosis-specific mechanisms.
population_specificity: HK-2 cells (renal tubule damage model) and streptozotocin-induced diabetic nephropathy rats.
effective_dosage: 0.23–30 μg/mL (in vitro), specific in vivo dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how elevated intracellular glutathione levels, mediated by AKR1C1 and STAT3 activation, contribute to oxaliplatin resistance in colorectal cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that AKR1C1 overexpression increases intracellular glutathione levels via EAAT3 upregulation, conferring oxaliplatin resistance. Inhibition of AKR1C1 with alantolactone reversed this resistance by reducing glutathione levels and restoring oxaliplatin sensitivity.
population_specificity: Oxaliplatin-resistant colorectal cancer cell lines (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the radioprotective effects of glutathione (measured via reduced and oxidized levels) in combination with cimetidine, famotidine, and vitamin C against gamma radiation-induced oxidative stress in mice.
results_summary: The study found that glutathione levels (both reduced and oxidized forms) increased with higher radiation doses, and vitamin C provided better protection than cimetidine or famotidine alone, while the combination of all three drugs showed excellent radioprotective effects.
population_specificity: Male mice (6-8 weeks old, 28 ± 3 g).
effective_dosage: Not specified for glutathione (only radiation doses of 2 and 4 Gy and varying doses of cimetidine, famotidine, and vitamin C were mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an amorphous-crystalline urchin-like TiO2 (AC-UL-TiO2) system for accurate identification and monitoring of glutathione (GSH) and its oxidized form (GSSG) in tumor microenvironments.
results_summary: The study found that AC-UL-TiO2 demonstrated excellent SERS performance for detecting GSH and GSSG, with a detection limit of 10^-8 M for direct SERS detection, 100 times higher than indirect detection. The system also enabled accurate monitoring of GSH concentrations (0-1000 µM) and could distinguish between GSH and GSSG molecules.
population_specificity: Tumor microenvironment (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects specified).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentration range: 0-1000 µM for monitoring).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a glutathione-responsive polypeptide nanogel for targeted tumor therapy and evaluate its efficacy in a breast cancer model.
results_summary: The glutathione-responsive nanogel (mPPC/SHK) demonstrated enhanced tumor inhibition, achieving a 69.97% inhibition rate in the 4T1 breast cancer model, with efficient drug release triggered by high glutathione concentrations.
population_specificity: 4T1 breast cancer model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how phytic acid treatment affects the antioxidant capacity and quality of Rosa roxburghii fruit, particularly focusing on the role of glutathione (GSH) in the ascorbate-glutathione (AsA-GSH) cycle during postharvest storage.
results_summary: Phytic acid treatment enhanced glutathione (GSH) levels, activated the AsA-GSH cycle, and improved the activity of key enzymes like glutathione reductase (GR), while reducing oxidized glutathione (GSSG) and oxidative damage in the fruit.
population_specificity: Postharvest Rosa roxburghii fruit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of 20% glutathione on the bond strength of composite resin to enamel after extra-coronal bleaching at two different time intervals.
results_summary: Group D (bleaching followed by glutathione application and composite restoration after one week) showed the highest shear bond strength compared to Group B (immediate restoration after glutathione treatment). Glutathione improved bond strength post-bleaching.
population_specificity: Forty extracted human molars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of glutathione (GSH) depletion in enhancing the anti-tumor efficacy of cisplatin (CDDP) and Cu2+ in a pH-sensitive hydrogel system for colon cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Cu2+ released from the hydrogel depleted GSH in tumor cells, which reduced CDDP-GSH binding and accelerated CDDP release, enhancing its anti-tumor effect. Additionally, GSH depletion protected hydroxyl radicals (OH•) from removal, improving chemodynamic therapy (CDT) efficacy.
population_specificity: Simulated tumor microenvironment (in vitro) and organoid models, focusing on colon cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of glutathione in reducing oxidative stress and enhancing immune defenses against Mycobacterium tuberculosis in the context of multidrug-resistant tuberculous meningitis (MDR-TBM).
results_summary: The study suggests glutathione may help mitigate oxidative stress and improve immune responses against Mtb, with potential benefits in MDR-TBM management. It also highlights the promise of vaccines targeting glutathione synthesis in macrophages to enhance treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with multidrug-resistant tuberculous meningitis (MDR-TBM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how rhizosphere bacteria affect glutathione-S-transferase (GST) activity and herbicide detoxification in wheat and canola plants exposed to metsulfuron-methyl (MSM).
results_summary: Bacterial treatment increased GST activity by 38-94% in plants and accelerated MSM degradation in soil by 54.6-79.7%, reducing ALS enzyme inhibition and mitigating herbicide toxicity.
population_specificity: Wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) and canola (Brassica napus L.) plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how the loss of glutathione-S-transferase Theta 2 (Gstt2) expression affects response to BCG immunotherapy in non-muscle-invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC).
results_summary: Gstt2 knockout mice showed upregulated pro-inflammatory TNF-α and enriched immune-activated cell types, while wildtype mice exhibited immunosuppressive PD-L1 expression and tumorigenic gene profiles. An 11-gene signature derived from the study predicted treatment response in NMIBC patients.
population_specificity: C57Bl/6J mice implanted with tumors and NMIBC patients from the TCGA database.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4) in corpus cavernosum smooth muscle cells (CCSMCs) under high-glucose conditions and its regulatory mechanisms, particularly via ubiquitin-mediated degradation.
results_summary: The study found that high glucose downregulates GPX4 expression in CCSMCs, increasing oxidative stress and ferroptosis, impairing smooth muscle relaxation. NEDD4, an E3 ubiquitin ligase, was identified as a key regulator of GPX4 stability through ubiquitin-proteasome degradation.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats and primary cultures of corpus cavernosum smooth muscle cells (CCSMCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the fluctuations of GSTα protein levels in mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer's disease (AD) and their correlation with cognitive function.
results_summary: Plasma GSTα protein levels were significantly lower in AD patients compared to controls and MCI patients, and changes in GSTα levels were positively correlated with cognitive decline. GSTα showed potential as a biomarker for MCI and AD, with strong predictive value.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (54), patients with mild cognitive impairment (345), and patients with Alzheimer's disease (96).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a nanoplatform (MTO) derived from metal-organic frameworks could deplete glutathione to enhance sonodynamic and chemodynamic therapy for tumor treatment.
results_summary: The study found that MTO effectively depleted glutathione in tumor sites, alleviating the suppressive tumor environment and enhancing immunogenic cell death, which activated a robust immune response. The combination of MTO-mediated therapy and PD-L1 blockade also induced systemic immunity and durable immune memory to inhibit tumor progression and metastasis.
population_specificity: Tumor-bearing models (not specified if human or animal, but likely preclinical based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a glutathione (GSH)-driven disassembly strategy could enhance the phototheranostic performance of hydrophobic organic phototherapeutic agents (OPTAs) in photodynamic therapy (PDT) and photothermal therapy (PTT).
results_summary: The study found that the GSH-driven disassembly strategy significantly improved ROS production (tenfold increase) and photothermal conversion efficiency (PCE of 77.03%), enhancing both PDT and PTT efficacy in planar OPTAs.
population_specificity: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) treatment (in vitro or preclinical context implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how lactate-mediated lactylation of NSUN2 enhances GCLC mRNA stabilization and intracellular GSH levels, thereby promoting resistance to ferroptosis in gastric cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that lactate-mediated lactylation of NSUN2 increases GCLC m5C modification and mRNA stability, leading to higher intracellular GSH levels, reduced lipid peroxidation, and resistance to ferroptosis induced by doxorubicin in gastric cancer cells. The effect was nearly abolished with NSUN2 K508R or GCLC C-A mutants.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cancer cells deficient in SWI/SNF components (other than ARID1A) are selectively sensitive to the GSH inhibitor eprenetapopt (APR-246).
results_summary: The study found that SMARCA4-, SMARCB1-, and PBRM1-deficient cells were more sensitive to eprenetapopt than SWI/SNF-proficient cells, due to reduced basal GSH levels and increased ROS, leading to apoptosis. Eprenetapopt showed promise as a selective treatment for SWI/SNF-deficient cancers.
population_specificity: Cancer cells deficient in SWI/SNF components (SMARCA4, SMARCB1, PBRM1) derived from lung cancers, rhabdoid tumors, and kidney cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of glutathione (GSH) in mitigating mitochondrial dysfunction and oxidative stress induced by depleted uranium (DU) exposure in renal cells.
results_summary: The study found that GSH levels were significantly reduced after DU exposure, and supplementation with the GSH precursor N-acetylcysteine increased ATP levels, reduced oxidative stress, and mitigated kidney damage. GSH also interacted with hydrogen sulfide (H2S) in the DU-induced injury pathway.
population_specificity: ETHE1 gene knockout C57BL/6 mice and renal cell models exposed to DU.
effective_dosage: 500 µM DU in renal cell models (exact GSH dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how nanozymes can deplete glutathione (GSH) to enhance reactive oxygen species (ROS)-based cancer therapies.
results_summary: The study found that nanozymes effectively generate ROS and selectively deplete GSH, improving the efficacy of photodynamic therapy, chemodynamic therapy, and radiotherapy in targeting cancer cells. The approach offers advantages over standard therapies by overcoming ROS-resistant cancer cells.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or preclinical models, not explicitly specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate miRNA expression changes in pediatric celiac disease patients and assess the impact of a gluten-free diet on these patterns.
results_summary: The study identified 8 dysregulated miRNAs in celiac patients, with some restored to normal levels after a gluten-free diet, suggesting a role in disease pathogenesis and dietary response.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with active celiac disease (n=20), celiac patients on a gluten-free diet (n=17), and a control group (n=29).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and refine a family-centered, online behavioral intervention (GROW Project) to improve quality of life and gluten-free diet self-management in adolescents with celiac disease and their parents.
results_summary: Stakeholder feedback supported a virtual, group-based format for the intervention, with suggested improvements to enhance engagement and content, including digital resources, resilience-building, and GFD-alcohol information. The GROW Project was found to address a critical need for behavioral self-management strategies in adolescents with celiac disease.
population_specificity: Adolescents with celiac disease and their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the glutenase potential of novel wheat proteases (Ta-P7, Ta-V6, and Triticain-α) for enzymatic treatment of gluten-related disorders, particularly celiac disease.
results_summary: The study found that Triticain-α and Ta-P7 effectively hydrolyzed gluten-derived toxic peptides under gastrointestinal conditions, with Triticain-α showing the highest efficiency. Both enzymes significantly reduced toxic peptide levels compared to untreated gluten or pepsin-trypsin digestion.
population_specificity: Susceptible individuals with gluten-related disorders (e.g., celiac disease).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different acid-based glycerolipids and thermomechanical treatments affect gluten functionalities, particularly its secondary structure and viscoelastic properties.
results_summary: Oleic acid increased the α-helix content and improved gluten viscoelasticity, while triolein and rapeseed oil reduced viscoelasticity but enhanced tensile properties. Thermomechanical treatment promoted gluten aggregation and disulfide bond formation, and molecular simulations identified hydrogen bonds and hydrophobic interactions as key forces in lipid-gluten binding.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on gluten properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an improved method (ultrasound-assisted xylanase treatment) for separating wheat starch from gluten to enhance efficiency and product quality.
results_summary: The study found that the ultrasound-assisted xylanase treatment (U-Xyl15) improved starch and gluten yields, enhanced gluten polymerization and viscoelasticity, and preserved starch quality by reducing damage to its crystalline structure. The treatment also improved the anti-retrogradation capacity of starch and resulted in higher gel strength.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on wheat starch-gluten separation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of ultrasound treatment on the techno-functional, thermal, structural, and rheological properties of a composite gluten-free flour.
results_summary: Sonication reduced water absorption capacity and swelling power while increasing oil absorption capacity and water solubility. It also lowered gelatinization enthalpy, enhanced gel elasticity, and caused particle fragmentation and surface roughening.
population_specificity: Composite gluten-free flour (corn starch, rice flour, and other ingredients).
effective_dosage: 10 min of sonication at 20 °C, hydration levels of 15% and 25% (w/w).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the novel wheat arabino-xylanase (PcXyn11A) could improve gluten matrix development and enhance whole wheat bread quality by degrading wheat arabinoxylan.
results_summary: PcXyn11A treatment improved gluten matrix structure, reduced dough retrogradation, increased gas retention, and delayed dough aging, leading to increased bread volume (11.45%) and reduced hardness (34.68%). The enzyme also exhibited anti-aging properties during storage.
population_specificity: Whole wheat dough and bread (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the experiences of patients with coeliac disease (CD) adhering to a gluten-free diet (GFD) in the UK and Australia.
results_summary: The study identified five key themes affecting patients' quality of life: acceptance and adaptation, dietary burden, cost burden, socialising, and importance of support. It highlighted the need for defined follow-up strategies to address the physical and psychological impacts of CD.
population_specificity: Patients with coeliac disease (CD) in the UK and Australia (n=198).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine contemporary rates of early mucosal recovery in children with celiac disease (CeD) following diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that 74% of children with CeD achieved mucosal recovery within 15 months of diagnosis, though 26% had persistent enteropathy. Musculoskeletal symptoms at diagnosis were associated with persistent enteropathy.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with celiac disease between 2016 and 2021 in Canada and the United States.
study_duration: Follow-up biopsy within 15 months of diagnosis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of extrusion on functional properties, nutritional value, and antioxidant activity of gluten-free snacks made from rice-chickpea flours fortified with Fibersol® and passion-fruit-skin flour.
results_summary: Extrusion reduced total phenolic compounds (12-30%) but preserved hydroxybenzoic acids as the majority. It significantly decreased trypsin inhibitor activity (86.7-95.8%) and maintained or reduced phytate content. Antioxidant activity varied, with DPPH and FRAP assays showing increased activity in some cases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how catalase (CAT) affects the rheological properties and structural changes of wheat gluten to understand the mechanisms behind these modifications.
results_summary: CAT significantly improved the storage and loss moduli of gluten while reducing creep and recovery strain, with optimal effects at 250 U/g for 30 minutes. It increased disulfide bonds and β-sheet content, enhancing gluten network stability and compactness.
population_specificity: Wheat gluten (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet (GFD) could improve negative symptoms, particularly anhedonia and avolition, in individuals with schizophrenia-related disorders (SRD) who had elevated anti-gliadin antibodies (AGA IgG).
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in negative symptoms (CAINS MAP) with a gluten-free diet compared to a gluten-containing diet, but no significant changes in other measures like cognition or overall psychiatric symptoms. Side effects were mild and similar between groups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-64 with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder, elevated AGA IgG (>20 U), no celiac disease, and stable antipsychotic treatment.
effective_dosage: 30 grams of gluten or rice flour daily delivered in protein shakes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary methionine restriction could suppress the celiac toxic effects of gluten in an in vivo model, mitigating intestine damage.
results_summary: The study found that dietary methionine restriction effectively ameliorated gluten-induced celiac-associated small intestine damage by modulating intestinal flora to inhibit butyric acid production, which in turn assisted in repairing intestine damage.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice (adolescent and adult)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether transamidated gliadin (GM) reduces celiac disease-related gluten toxicity in cellular and animal models.
results_summary: GM mitigated intestinal damage and pro-inflammatory responses in Caco-2 cells and BMDCs, and in BALB/c mice, it reduced pro-inflammatory factors and improved microbiome balance compared to unmodified gliadin.
population_specificity: Caco-2 cell monolayers, bone marrow-derived dendritic cells (BMDCs), and BALB/c mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of gluten and wheat in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and noncoeliac gluten or wheat sensitivity (NCGWS), and to evaluate the effectiveness of gluten- or wheat-free diets in these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the role of gluten in IBS and NCGWS remains complex, with antigliadin antibodies potentially identifying IBS patients who may benefit from a gluten-free diet. Evidence for a gluten-free diet is debatable, while a wheat-free diet may be more effective, particularly in NCGWS.
population_specificity: Individuals with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and noncoeliac gluten or wheat sensitivity (NCGWS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ultrasonic treatment at varying power levels affects the rheology, water distribution, and gluten properties of FXL dough.
results_summary: Ultrasonic treatment at 300 W improved gluten network formation, altered water distribution (increasing tightly bound water), and enhanced protein polymerization. Higher power (500 W) disrupted the gluten network, exposing starch particles.
population_specificity: FXL (Long-chain inulin) dough
effective_dosage: Ultrasonic power levels (0 W, 200 W, 250 W, 300 W, 400 W, 500 W)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prevalence of anemia in adults and children with Celiac Disease (CD) at diagnosis and during a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found no significant change in anemia prevalence after 3-5 years of GFD, but a significant reduction in adult patients after 8-10 years (24% to 17.8%). Anemia persisted in 17.8% of adults and 4.4% of pediatric patients despite long-term GFD.
population_specificity: 311 CD patients (184 adults and 127 pediatric patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the osteoclastogenic potential in celiac disease patients and the longitudinal changes in bone metabolism after long-term gluten-free diet (GFD) treatment.
results_summary: The study found that osteoclastogenesis was higher in active celiac disease patients and remained elevated even after GFD, but BMD improved post-GFD. OPG and IL-6 were associated with bone health markers, suggesting OPG as a risk marker for osteopenia/osteoporosis in celiac disease.
population_specificity: Adult active celiac disease patients (newly diagnosed and untreated) and those after long-term GFD adherence, compared to healthy donors.
study_duration: Long-term adherence to GFD (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a reliable and efficient electrochemical immunoplatform for detecting gluten in food products to ensure compliance with gluten-free standards for celiac disease management.
results_summary: The study successfully developed a highly sensitive immunoplatform capable of detecting gluten at low concentrations (1.4 ng mL-1) and discriminating between gluten-free and gluten-containing foods according to legal thresholds. The method showed agreement with established ELISA and qPCR techniques, offering faster results (60 minutes post-extraction).
population_specificity: Processed foodstuffs (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an analytical method to detect 3,5-DHCA as a biomarker of gluten intake in urine to monitor adherence to a gluten-free diet in celiac patients.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the HPTLC-based method effectively detected 3,5-DHCA in urine, correlating with gluten intake, and showed good sensitivity, precision, and recovery rates. The method is promising for monitoring dietary transgressions in celiac patients.
population_specificity: Celiac patients and control patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate overlooked aspects of enzyme development for gluten digestion, focusing on mode-of-action, target organ, and drug delivery challenges.
results_summary: The study found that most gluten-digesting enzymes are gastric endopeptidases with limited effectiveness due to poor enzyme-substrate exposure and incomplete digestion. Exopeptidases, though critical for generating absorbable fractions, remain underexplored and require functional combinations and stabilization for therapeutic use.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on enzyme development for gluten digestion, likely relevant to coeliac disease patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether corn protein activity peptides (CPAPs) could reduce inflammation and improve gastrointestinal microbiota in mice infected with H. pylori.
results_summary: CPAPs reduced H. pylori colonization, improved anti-inflammatory responses, and enhanced microbiota diversity and function, suggesting potential benefits for metabolic disorders linked to H. pylori.
population_specificity: H. pylori-infected mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on brain bioelectrical activity and neurological symptoms in children with celiac disease (CeD).
results_summary: Over half of newly diagnosed CeD children exhibited neurological symptoms, particularly headaches, which notably reduced after six months on a GFD. EEG abnormalities were more prevalent in CeD patients compared to healthy controls, but improved with dietary intervention.
population_specificity: 85 children (18 newly diagnosed CeD, 27 CeD patients on GFD for over 12 months, and 40 healthy controls).
study_duration: 6 months for newly diagnosed CeD group

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Hellenic version of the Celiac Disease Adherence Test (H-CDAT) and assess the impact of gluten-free diet adherence on health-related quality of life in Greek celiac disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that strict adherence to a gluten-free diet significantly improved health-related quality of life, with notable differences between good and moderate adherence levels. Patients with poor adherence scored lower across most HRQoL dimensions compared to the general Greek population.
population_specificity: 102 adult celiac disease patients in Greece.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether total alkylresorcinol concentration is a valid biomarker for gluten intake in young children.
results_summary: The study found that alkylresorcinol concentrations increased significantly with gluten intake in young children, suggesting it may be a useful biomarker. The intervention group on a gluten-free diet had markedly lower alkylresorcinol levels compared to controls.
population_specificity: 65 children aged 18 months, including an intervention group on a gluten-free diet (n=21) and a control group with unrestricted diet (n=44).
effective_dosage: Gluten intake in controls was median 5.8 grams/day (IQR: 2.8-9.4, max 17.1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review investigational therapies for coeliac disease as alternatives or supplements to a gluten-free diet.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the challenges of maintaining a gluten-free diet and the need for pharmacological treatments, noting ongoing phase 2/3 trials for new therapies.
population_specificity: Genetically susceptible individuals with coeliac disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether gluten-free diets could alleviate autoimmune inflammatory processes in Sjögren's syndrome (SS) patients, with or without celiac disease (CD), and the potential benefits of potassium-rich, gluten-free diets.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in SS patients with CD on a gluten-free diet, normalization of serum potassium levels in CD patients, and potential therapeutic benefits of combining gluten-free and potassium-rich diets in SS patients with low potassium levels.
population_specificity: Sjögren's syndrome (SS) patients, including those with and without celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on HbA1c levels in children with both type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and celiac disease (CD).
results_summary: The study found no significant change in HbA1c levels before and after GFD therapy in children with T1DM and CD. Children with CD exhibited lower weight and height percentiles compared to those without CD.
population_specificity: 174 children with T1DM (93 girls, 81 boys), of whom 18 had CD.
study_duration: HbA1c was assessed six and twelve months after GFD initiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the bidirectional relationship between celiac disease (CD) and eating disorders (EDs), focusing on how gluten ingestion triggers CD and how dietary restrictions may foster disordered eating behaviors.
results_summary: The study found that CD and EDs share overlapping symptoms, complicating diagnosis and treatment. It highlighted a bidirectional risk, where CD individuals are at increased risk for EDs and vice versa, suggesting the need for integrated screening and care strategies.
population_specificity: Adolescents with celiac disease and/or eating disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map the digestion of gluten-derived immunogenic peptides along the gastrointestinal tract and assess the impact of actinidin as an exogenous protease.
results_summary: The study found that digestion of gluten immunogenic peptides is limited along the GIT but can be enhanced by simultaneous intake of proteases like actinidin, which doubled the digestion rate of wheat proteins in the stomach and reduced immunogenic peptide release.
population_specificity: Entire male pigs (9 weeks old, 19.3 ± 1.9 kg bodyweight).
effective_dosage: Green kiwifruit (27.0 U protease actinidin activity/mL fresh juice) or yellow kiwifruit (0 U protease actinidin activity/mL fresh juice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how transglutaminase (TG) affects the rheological properties and structural changes of wheat gluten.
results_summary: TG treatment increased gluten's storage and loss moduli while reducing creep and recovery strains, indicating improved rheological properties. It promoted gluten aggregation by elevating glutenin subunits, reducing gliadins, and forming disulfide bonds, leading to a more robust network structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on wheat gluten)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of microwave treatment combined with lysine and arginine on the structural and digestibility properties of gluten-free quinoa sponge cakes.
results_summary: The study found that microwave treatment with lysine and arginine significantly increased the cakes' specific volume and crystallinity, improved protein digestibility, and resulted in a denser protein network structure around starch granules during digestion. However, starch digestibility was lower in microwave-treated cakes.
population_specificity: Gluten-free quinoa sponge cakes (in vitro study, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the diagnostic accuracy of urinary gluten immunogenic peptide in identifying villous atrophy in patients with coeliac disease.
results_summary: The study found that urinary gluten immunogenic peptide had low sensitivity and specificity for detecting villous atrophy across different patient groups, concluding it is not a reliable marker and endoscopy remains necessary.
population_specificity: Patients with coeliac disease, including asymptomatic individuals, those with non-responsive coeliac disease, and refractory coeliac disease on immunosuppressive therapy.
study_duration: Data collected from September 2018 to August 2023 (retrospective study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits and risks of a gluten-free diet (GFD) in both celiac and non-celiac populations, focusing on its effects on health and IBS-like disorders.
results_summary: The study found that while a GFD is beneficial for celiac disease, it may cause nutritional deficiencies, socio-psychological adversities, and exacerbate IBS-like disorders in non-celiac individuals. The abstract highlights the need for careful clinical evaluation before and during a GFD.
population_specificity: Celiac and non-celiac individuals, particularly those with IBS-like disorders.
interactions: Increased consumption of FODMAP-rich foods and histamine intolerance may interact negatively with a GFD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gluten-free dietary adherence between individuals with concurrent type 1 diabetes (T1D) and celiac disease (CeD) versus CeD alone and evaluate the utility of urinary gluten immunogenic peptide (GIP) testing in an outpatient setting.
results_summary: The study found higher gluten exposure (15% positive urinary GIP) in T1D+CeD participants compared to CeD-only participants (0% positive), suggesting poorer dietary adherence in the T1D+CeD group. Urinary GIP testing was effective in detecting recent gluten exposure, particularly in T1D-only participants (86% positive).
population_specificity: Adults with T1D and CeD, CeD only, or T1D only.
study_duration: Single urine sample collection (12 pm-7 pm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of FODMAP and low-FODMAP diets on symptom relief in celiac disease (CD) and non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS) patients adhering to a gluten-free diet (GFD).
results_summary: The study found that a low-FODMAP diet (LFD) could provide symptom relief in CD patients on a GFD and improve gastrointestinal symptoms in NCGS. Additionally, an LFD may improve psychological status in these populations, though it does not significantly impact gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (CD) on a gluten-free diet (GFD) and those with non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate factors influencing adherence to a gluten-free diet in people with celiac disease in Paraguay.
results_summary: The study found that 51.7% of participants had good adherence to the gluten-free diet, and 56.2% showed good adaptation. Prolonged time since diagnosis and family support were significantly associated with better adherence.
population_specificity: Adolescent and adult subjects with celiac disease in Paraguay (median age 33 years, 85.3% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the umami intensity, taste mechanism, and antioxidant activity of six umami peptides derived from wheat gluten hydrolysates (WGHs) and fermented WGHs.
results_summary: The study found that the peptides exhibited umami-enhancing properties and antioxidant activity in vitro, with molecular dynamics simulations showing interactions with T1R1/T1R3 receptors. Network pharmacology and molecular docking suggested potential core targets (AKT1, JUN, CASP3) for treating oxidative diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of celiac disease (CD) and a 1-year gluten-free diet (GFD) on gut function and microbiome composition.
results_summary: CD patients showed altered gut function (higher small bowel water content, delayed whole gut transit time) and microbiome composition (high proteolytic gene functions, reduced Bifidobacteria). GFD improved well-being and partially normalized gut function and microbiota but did not fully reverse CD-associated changes.
population_specificity: 36 newly diagnosed celiac disease patients and 36 healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of gut microbiota in gluten-related disorders (GRD) and assess the potential of probiotics/prebiotics in managing these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that gluten-related disorders (celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, and wheat allergy) are associated with distinct gut microbiota dysbiosis, which persists despite a gluten-free diet. Probiotics may help mitigate some adverse effects of gluten contamination and improve outcomes in these disorders.
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten-related disorders (celiac disease, non-celiac gluten sensitivity, and wheat allergy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare adherence to a gluten-free diet (GFD) and identify barriers faced by children with both Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) and Celiac Disease (CD) versus those with CD alone.
results_summary: Gluten adherence was worse in the T1DMCD group compared to the CD-only group, with financial burden, disease unawareness, limited GFD availability, and social isolation being significant barriers. The study highlighted the need for better awareness and management strategies for children with dual diagnoses.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-14 years with either T1DM and CD (n=30) or CD alone (n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare baseline characteristics and serology normalization in children diagnosed with Celiac Disease (CeD) with or without biopsies, focusing on treatment adherence and serology decline.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the rate of TTG decline or treatment adherence between children diagnosed with CeD via biopsy or without biopsy, suggesting similar short-term outcomes regardless of diagnostic method. Baseline characteristics, including symptoms, were also similar between groups.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (ages 2.4-17.9 years) diagnosed with Celiac Disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the emulsifying capabilities of modified wheat gluten (M-WG) in ice cream compared to monoglycerides (MG) and soy protein isolates (SPI).
results_summary: M-WG demonstrated comparable emulsifying capabilities to MG and SPI, with smaller droplet sizes and more consistent dispersion. Ice cream made with M-WG also showed better overrun and meltdown rates, along with good sensory characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food product testing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an updated understanding of gluten-related disorders (GRDs), focusing on celiac disease (CD) and non-celiac gluten sensitivity (NCGS), and to highlight the role of gluten-free diets (GFD) in managing these conditions.
results_summary: The study found that gluten triggers intestinal damage in celiac disease and causes symptoms in NCGS, though without immunological reactions. Advances in understanding GRDs include insights into intestinal microbiota's role, and GFD remains the standard therapy despite challenges.
population_specificity: Individuals with gluten-related disorders (celiac disease and non-celiac gluten sensitivity).

study_goal: The researchers sought to understand how New Zealanders with coeliac disease (CD) obtain gluten-free (GF) products and the factors influencing their choices.
results_summary: The study found low uptake (2%) of GF foods on prescription, with cost, limited product range, and lack of awareness being key barriers. Most respondents preferred financial support via a discount card over prescription services.
population_specificity: Members of Coeliac New Zealand (522 respondents).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest innovations in therapies for Celiac Disease (CD), focusing on alternative treatments to a gluten-free diet, including pharmacologic strategies targeting gluten-related immune responses.
results_summary: The study highlights that gluten exacerbates CD by triggering an autoimmune response, leading to intestinal damage, and discusses emerging therapies like enzymatic degradation of gluten, immunomodulation, and nanoparticle-based treatments to mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with Celiac Disease (genetically susceptible to gluten-induced autoimmune responses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adopting a gluten-free diet (GFD) in children with celiac disease (CeD) increases their exposure to arsenic.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in urinary arsenic concentration (from 3.3 µg/L to 13.6 µg/L) after 6 months on a GFD. Family history of CeD and Hispanic ethnicity were associated with higher arsenic levels.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-18 years with newly diagnosed celiac disease, predominantly White and from a middle-class, well-educated background.
